comment.author: 54447542@N00
comment._content: This hangar later became a "boat barn" for Officers stationed at NAS Corpus Christi

comment.author: 15283643@N04
comment._content:
She can't be painting the insignia free-hand. Either the photo is staged, or she's just touching up the edges. Her arms are resting on the painted surface, so it must be dry.

Bad form, resting a paint can on a fabric-covered wing.

comment.author: 15283643@N04
comment._content:
The alternate version of this shot is really bad: terrible lighting and background clutter (wash-up sink and red arrow); the bottom edge of the paint can is pressed into the fabric of the wing; and Irma's left hand is curled under. 

It wasn't an easy shot. She's painting the top wing of a biplane, so she must be perched on a ladder or scaffolding. It looks like they just moved the camera to hide the sink in the other version.

 [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2178437377]

comment.author: 11582765@N00
comment._content:
I'm with technogeo. I can't believe they wouldn't have used stencils or at the minimum masking tape and such for painting the insignia on aircraft when this photo was taken. Also the smooth surface that can be seen where the reflection is leeds me to believe that the paint was applied with a spray gun. I don't even think that she is touching up the edges because of the size of the brush. My conclusion is that this photo is staged. Its a great photo anyway.
Dave

comment.author: 15283643@N04
comment._content:
It looks like she's painting the top wing of a biplane like the ones in this other photo. She's pretty high off the ground, leaning over the leading edge.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2179227174]

comment.author: 15283643@N04
comment._content:
My mistake! There is masking tape along the edge of the star! If you look closely at the largest image, you'll see light beige strips where the white meets the navy blue background. The tape is most visible at the two points of the star in the foreground. It runs onto the surrounding yellow color. 

My guess is that they painted a white circle first, then added the dark blue to create the star, but that would have been pretty complicated. Easier to paint the white on top of the blue, but how could it cover so well?

comment.author: 15283643@N04
comment._content:
What factory painters and painting an insignia really looked like during the war:

[http://flickr.com/photos/15283643@N04/3001582828/]

comment.author: 15283643@N04
comment._content: Here's a close-up of the crest on Irma's overalls: "We Keep Them Flying US CC NAS " (US Corpus Christi Naval Air Station)

comment.author: 15283643@N04
comment._content: She's wearing Pay Day overalls.

comment.author: 15283643@N04
comment._content: Photo ID from alternate image no. 34906 - mug shot of Irma without make-up. The writing under the photo reads "A&R McElroy I.L." "A & R " is for "Assembly & Repair"

comment.author: 15283643@N04
comment._content:
A third version of this subject, with a different worker. Same wing, same can of paint. The text for this one refers to painting the American insignia "on repaired Navy plane wings."



[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2178435033/]
